item.title: 【General Music Discussion】Is it true that Qobuz & UMG putting hidden watermarks on songs?
item.description:
I recently came across an article about how UMG putting hidden watermarks on songs and providing them to music stores and streaming services like Qobuz, Tidal, Spotify, and Apple Music. I wanna know if this watermarking situation is still in use, because I recently downloaded Britney Spears discography on Sharemania from someone who gets songs from Qobuz. Can any of you tell me if they're still doing this? if they don't, did they replaced watermarked versions of songs with originals?
The article that I'm talking about:
https://www.mattmontag.com/music/universals-audible-watermark
item.author: Britneyssbloverr

item.title: 【Albums (lossy)】Dolby Atmos - Whitney Houston - "Whitney" (1987) [Apple Spatial Audio with Dolby Atmos 5.1 Surround Sound]
item.description:
"Whitney" (1987)
[Dolby Atmos mix from Apple Music]
​
FORMAT: .WAV
QUALITY: Apple Spatial Audio with Dolby Atmos
GENRE: R&B/Soul
RELEASED: 1987-06-02​

TRACKLIST:
1. I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)
2. Just the Lonely Talking Again
3. Love Will Save the Day
4. Didn't We Almost Have It All
5. So Emotional
6. Where You Are
7. Love Is a Contact Sport
8. You're Still My Man
9. For the Love of You
10. Where Do Broken Hearts Go
11. I Know Him So Well (duet with Cissy Houston)

Whitney Houston's second album, "Whitney" (1987), cemented her status as a global superstar. It showcased her powerful and soulful voice, instantly capturing the hearts of millions of fans. The album delivered hit after hit, including chart-topping singles like "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)," "Didn't We Almost Have It All," and "So Emotional," and "Where Do Broken Hearts Go." Whitney's vocal range and emotional depth shone through in each song, solidifying her as one of the greatest vocalists of all time. "Whitney" was a commercial and critical success, breaking records and further catapulting Houston into the music industry's elite.
